content.title: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
content.summary: Transient neurologic dysfunction from focal cerebral ischemia without infarction
key_points: TIA is a medical emergency - high short-term stroke risk
Current definition: tissue-based (no infarction on imaging)
Urgent workup: brain imaging, vessel imaging, cardiac evaluation
Dual antiplatelet (DAPT) for 21-90 days reduces stroke risk
30% of strokes are preceded by TIA

statement.text: Transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a transient episode of neurologic dysfunction caused by focal brain, spinal cord, or retinal ischemia without acute infarction. TIA is a warning sign with high short-term stroke risk (5-10% at 48 hours), requiring urgent evaluation and secondary prevention.
statement.formal: TIA = Transient focal neurologic deficit + No infarction on imaging → Urgent workup + DAPT + Risk factor modification

explanation.intuition: A TIA is like a 'warning stroke' - the brain briefly loses blood supply but recovers before permanent damage. The danger is that the same mechanism (clot, stenosis) that caused the TIA can cause a complete stroke soon after.
explanation.key_insight: The old definition (symptoms <24 hours) is outdated. Modern imaging shows many patients with brief symptoms still have DWI-positive infarcts. The new tissue-based definition focuses on whether there's permanent injury, regardless of symptom duration.

definitions_glossary.TIA: Transient ischemic attack - focal ischemia without infarction
definitions_glossary.tissue_based_definition: TIA defined by absence of infarction on imaging, not symptom duration
definitions_glossary.ABCD2_score: Risk stratification: Age, BP, Clinical features, Duration, Diabetes
definitions_glossary.crescendo_TIA: Multiple TIAs in short period; high stroke risk
definitions_glossary.high_risk_TIA: Symptoms >60 min, motor/speech involvement, ABCD2 ≥4, symptomatic stenosis
definitions_glossary.dual_antiplatelet_therapy: Aspirin + clopidogrel for 21-90 days after TIA
definitions_glossary.carotid_stenosis: Narrowing of carotid artery; common TIA mechanism
definitions_glossary.DWI_positive_TIA: MRI shows restricted diffusion despite transient symptoms - technically a stroke
definitions_glossary.lacunar_syndrome: Distinct clinical pattern suggesting small vessel disease
definitions_glossary.amaurosis_fugax: Transient monocular vision loss from retinal ischemia, often from carotid disease
definitions_glossary.watershed_infarct: Infarct at junction of vascular territories from hypoperfusion
definitions_glossary.crescendo_symptoms: Multiple TIAs occurring within short timeframe indicating high stroke risk

pathophysiology.mechanism: Same as ischemic stroke (embolic, thrombotic, hypoperfusion) but ischemia resolves before irreversible injury. May be from spontaneous clot lysis, collateral flow, or transient hemodynamic insufficiency.

TIA_vs_mimics.TIA_features: Sudden onset, focal, negative symptoms (weakness, numbness, vision loss)
TIA_vs_mimics.mimics: Migraine with aura (spreading, visual), seizure (positive symptoms, postictal), hypoglycemia, syncope

workup.brain_imaging: MRI with DWI preferred (detects small infarcts); CT if MRI unavailable
workup.vessel_imaging: CTA or MRA of head and neck (identify stenosis, dissection)
workup.cardiac_evaluation: ECG (AF), echocardiogram (thrombus, PFO), extended cardiac monitoring if cryptogenic

ABCD2_score.limitations: Doesn't include imaging findings or vessel status; clinical judgment needed

antiplatelets.DAPT: Aspirin + clopidogrel for 21-90 days (CHANCE, POINT trials)
antiplatelets.single_agent: After DAPT period, continue single antiplatelet long-term

treatment_options.statin: High-intensity statin (atorvastatin 80mg) for all atherosclerotic TIA
treatment_options.anticoagulation: If AF identified → DOAC (may start after imaging excludes large infarct)

carotid_intervention.procedure: CEA or CAS based on anatomy and comorbidities

definition.@value: Transient neurologic dysfunction from focal cerebral, spinal, or retinal ischemia without infarction on imaging

learning_objectives: Calculate ABCD2 score for risk stratification
clinical_pearls: TIA is a stroke warning - 5-10% stroke risk at 48 hours
DAPT (aspirin + clopidogrel) × 21-90 days reduces recurrence (CHANCE, POINT)
If DWI positive, it's technically a stroke even if symptoms resolved
Urgent carotid imaging - intervention most beneficial within 2 weeks
Extended cardiac monitoring (up to 30 days) often reveals paroxysmal AF

sources.source: Easton JD, et al. AHA/ASA TIA Definition and Evaluation. Stroke 2009
